instruction: Rinse the jeerakasala rice 2–3 times until the water runs clear. Soak it in water for 30 minutes.
title: Soak Jeerakasala Rice

transcript_segments.text: Welcome to T-South Chennai! Today, as many of you requested, I’m going to show you my favorite – Kerala-style Thalassery Chicken Biryani. This biryani is very flavorful and has a rich, traditional taste.
If you have nutmeg, take a small piece. I’m using nutmeg powder here and will add it as powder. Now we can dry roast everything.
Once it's roasted, you’ll immediately get a great aroma. Now just sauté it until it's nice and aromatic.
Take around 8 pieces of green chili – you can adjust based on how spicy you want it. This amount was perfect for us. Don’t grind these – use them as is.

instruction: Heat oil in a pan. Add thinly sliced onions and shallow-fry on medium heat until golden brown. Remove and drain on paper towels.
title: Fry Onions for Garnishing

transcript_segments.text: Once the oil is hot, add three sliced onions. Sauté well. No need to brown completely – just soften them enough.

instruction: In the same or a separate pan, heat ghee and sauté cashews until golden. Add raisins and sauté until they puff up. Set aside for garnishing.
title: Sauté Cashews and Raisins

transcript_segments.text: Once the oil is hot, add three sliced onions. Sauté well. No need to brown completely – just soften them enough.

instruction: In a bowl, mix chicken with a little salt and turmeric. Let it sit for about 10 minutes.
title: Marinate Chicken Lightly

transcript_segments.text: Sauté until the raw smell goes. Now we can add the chicken. I’m using a whole chicken weighing around 800 grams. Cook until it changes color slightly.

instruction: Heat oil in a heavy-bottomed pan. Add the marinated chicken and sear on high heat until the outside is lightly browned.
title: Sear the Chicken

transcript_segments.text: Sauté until the raw smell goes. Now we can add the chicken. I’m using a whole chicken weighing around 800 grams. Cook until it changes color slightly.

instruction: Lower the heat and add ginger-garlic paste. Sauté until raw smell disappears. Add green chilies and chopped tomatoes. Cook until tomatoes soften.
title: Add Aromatics and Tomatoes

transcript_segments.text: Add 1/4 tsp of turmeric powder. Then add 1 tbsp of the biryani masala paste. In this biryani, only green chilies are used for heat.
Add about half a cup each of mint and coriander leaves. Sauté for a while. The tomatoes should soften. Add half a cup of curd at this stage and mix well.

instruction: Mix in red chili powder, coriander powder, and garam masala. Stir well. Add yogurt and cook until the masala thickens and coats the chicken.
title: Add Spices and Yogurt

transcript_segments.text: Add about half a cup each of mint and coriander leaves. Sauté for a while. The tomatoes should soften. Add half a cup of curd at this stage and mix well.

instruction: Cover the pan and cook the chicken on low heat until tender and fully cooked. Stir occasionally to prevent burning.
title: Simmer Chicken Until Cooked

transcript_segments.text: Add the juice of one lemon. Cover and cook. Don’t add any water – chicken releases enough juices. Cook on low flame for about 10 minutes.
Once it turns light golden, stop frying. Don't over-fry or it’ll darken and not taste good. This is the perfect color. Heat 2 tbsp of ghee in a new pan.

instruction: In a separate large vessel, bring ample water to a boil. Add whole spices, salt, and a few drops of oil.
title: Boil Water with Whole Spices

transcript_segments.text: Once onions turn golden, remove them. Fry some raisins. In the same ghee, fry 2 pieces of cinnamon, 4 cloves, and 4 cardamoms.

instruction: Add the soaked rice to the boiling water. Cook until 90% done – the grains should be soft but still firm in the center. Drain and set aside.
title: Cook the Rice

transcript_segments.text: We had soaked the jeera samba rice earlier. You don’t have to soak too long, but a little is good.

instruction: In a deep pot, spread the cooked chicken masala at the bottom. Layer half of the cooked rice on top.
title: Layer Chicken and Rice

transcript_segments.text: We already added salt to the masala. Now add required salt for the rice. Mix well, close the lid, and let it sit like you would for ghee rice.
Let’s open and check the chicken. I kept it on low flame. See how thick the masala is? Now add the fried onions and mix well. That’s it – masala is ready.
After 5 minutes, rice is ready. Mix with the masala and prepare for dum. Turn the gas back on low flame. Add mint and coriander on top again.

instruction: Sprinkle half of the chopped mint, coriander, fried onions, and lemon juice over the rice layer.
title: Add Herbs and Garnishes

transcript_segments.text: After 5 minutes, rice is ready. Mix with the masala and prepare for dum. Turn the gas back on low flame. Add mint and coriander on top again.

instruction: Add the remaining rice as the second layer. Top with the rest of the mint, coriander, and fried onions.
title: Repeat Layering

transcript_segments.text: Top it with some fried onions and raisins. Keep layering as needed.
Sprinkle a bit more of the biryani masala. Again, add mint, coriander, and fried raisins. Optionally add some saffron milk too.

instruction: Cover the pot with a tight lid or seal with dough. Place over very low heat and cook for 15–20 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
title: Seal and Dum Cook

transcript_segments.text: Now close the pan and dum for 15–20 minutes. First 5 minutes on high, then 10 minutes low. Then place a dosa tawa under the pot and dum another 10 minutes on low.

instruction: Let the biryani rest for 10 minutes after dum. This helps settle the layers and enhance flavor.
title: Rest Before Serving

transcript_segments.text: Now close the pan and dum for 15–20 minutes. First 5 minutes on high, then 10 minutes low. Then place a dosa tawa under the pot and dum another 10 minutes on low.

instruction: Gently fluff the top rice with a fork. Garnish with fried cashews and raisins before serving.
title: Garnish and Serve
